intro: Zostera asiatica, commonly known as the Asian eelgrass, is a marine flowering plant belonging to the family Zosteraceae. It is characterized by its ribbon-like, grass-like leaves that are typically 10–30 cm long and arranged in a dense, underwater turf. This plant thrives in shallow coastal waters and estuaries, where it forms extensive meadows that provide habitat for various marine species. Zostera asiatica plays a crucial role in stabilizing sediments and improving water quality through its extensive root system. It is also an important component of seagrass ecosystems, contributing to biodiversity and carbon sequestration.
